Award.AwardTitle: Microbial Conversion of Greenhouse Gases into Fermentation-Ready Sugars

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1605031
Kalyuzhnaya, Marina

Human-related activities, such as fossil fuel production, agriculture, landfill use, and municipal wastewater are major contributors to global methane emission. Widespread and steady growth of these man-made emissions make methane not only a major contributor to climate change but also the primary target for near-term climate regulation. In this project a new dry fermentation process for biological methane utilization will be developed. This process is based on the unique ability of salt-loving, methane-consuming bacteria to not only stay active in an immobilized state without water supplementation but also to accumulate sugar in response to low water availability. Dry fermentation merges the full potential of biological systems with technology development to address affordable methane mitigation.

Proposed is the development of an array of micro-fibers with active methane-consuming cells engineered to convert methane into extractable sucrose. The specific aims of the proposal include (i) the rational modification of microbial catalysts to enhance sucrose production capabilities by reducing ectoine, glycogen and (exo)polysaccharides synthesis; (ii) the rational modification of the microbial catalyst to reduce oxygen consumption, including overexpression of bacteriohemerythrin to improve oxygen consumption, and development of strain-specific vectors for rapid integration of large DNA fragments; (iii) the lab-scale design and validation of the developed Dry Fermentation Module by investigating water-stress impacts on methane consumption and sucrose accumulation rates in methanotrophic 'living' micro-fibers. The proposed modules could represent a transformative solution for methane conversion into useful products. The module could be developed further into air-purifying cartridges that could be implemented at any hot-spot of methane emission, as a sustainable alternative to gas flare. The metagenomic libraries constructed in this project represent a novel approach for natural products discovery with a non-traditional host. The project will actively involve graduate, undergraduate, and high school students and encourage cross-disciplinary collaboration and establish partnerships with industry.
This award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we proposed to explore the applicability of native methane consuming bacteria for capturing anthropogenic methane emissions using a Dry Fermentation Module (DFM). The DFM was envisioned as an array of micro-fibers with immobilized active methane-consuming cells engineered to capture methane at low water availability. Our research focused on improving the understanding of the fundamentals of biological methane oxidation for efficient fermentation with methane as a feedstock, testing the long-term viability of methanotrophic bacteria and engineering living biomaterials methane capturing. The project outcomes include seven published peer-reviewed publications and one patent application. Three publications were co-authored with SDSU undergraduate students, and all publications were co-authored by Ph.D. or Master students.

Commercialization. The DMF development led to a new methane-mitigation technology, named Living Emission Abolish Filters(LEAFs) to remove methane from industrial sites where methane is released. We partnered with two coal-mine management teams—to advance our technology toward sustainable methane mitigation at coal mines. 

 Broader Impact. The "Methane Biocatalysis: Paving the Way for Sustainability" book comprises 19 chapters from experts and summarizes the most recent developments in the field, from fundamental discoveries to industrial implementation of methane-biocatalysis. We compiled an "SDSU/Summer: Professional Pathways in Biology" program, which offered a series of workshops covering various professional development areas for biology students. A "C1-biocatalysis: boot camp" training for students and researchers from both industry and academia was also established. Educational materials for the Encyclopedia of Microbiology v4/Reference Module in Life Sciences were prepared. One postdoc, four graduate students, and twelve undergraduate students (eight women, five minorities, and two underprivileged students) were trained. The results of the project were presented at six invited and numerous international and regional conferences. Eight undergraduate students shared their research at an SDSU Undergraduate Research Symposium and the annual SW-ASM meeting. Two students (both women) received the prestigious SC-ASM award for outstanding research. Three undergraduate students (two women, a minority) received internships with a biotech company focused on methane biocatalysis; one student was awarded a Science Undergraduate Laboratory Internship (DOE-SULI). Summer research internships ("Summer in the C1-lab" for 3–5 students per year) for high-school students were established.
